doc.title: Provisioning
doc.paragraph: When Adaptive Objects are committed to an adapter store, a record of the event, may optionally be recorded by a Journal Adapter in order to maintain a chronological ordering of events, which may be used to notify external clients. Provisioning describes the process by which Adaptive Objects may be synchronized between an adapter and one or more clients, or Provisioning Peers.

section.title: Journal
section.paragraph: Any adapter may be configured with an optional journalAdapterId, which references an adapter that supports the Journaling of object events. When an object is modified through the adapter interface methods (add, delete, modify, replace, update), a Journal Entry of the event is created and sent to the provided Journal Adapter. This Journal Entry contains information about the event, including the Request and Source information about the entry. The Journal Entry is added to an event queue, and each entry is referenced by a Journal Cursor. Cursors are used to uniquely identify an Journal Entry and entries may be fetched from the queue in chronological order, using these chain of cursors. The cursors may be used by both the Provisioning Peer and Journal Adapter to replay a series of events that have occurred from any range within the Journal.

A Journal Entry is produced for the Journal Adapter, by a single Provisioning Peer. The Journal Entry may then be consumed by one or more Provisioning Peers. The Journal Interface routines provide all of the necessary functions to provision in and out of the Journal. For more details on the Journal interface functions, see Journal.

A Producer is anything that produces an event that will be journaled. In the following diagram, we illustrate how a Provisioning Peer may produce an event simply by calling the add_object() routine to an adapter. The adapter, in turn, is configured with a Journal Adapter, which knows to take the object and add it to its queue of Journal Entries.

section.paragraph: By contrast, an Consumer is a client that consumes events from the Journal. These clients interact directly with the Journal Adapter itself by calling Journal routines that can fetch the first event, or an event after a positional cursor. When consumed, the event is removed from the Journal through a request to mark it consumed.

section.title: Provisioning Peers
section.paragraph: A Provisioning Peer is a client, external to the Journal, which may produce and/or consume Journal Entries. Provisioning Peers are uniquely identified by a peerId, which associates a peer with the following Provisioning Peer object properties:

When Provisioning Peers call journal functions, the peerId that is specified by the peering client, should be authenticated and authorized in order to deliver the appropriate data to the Provisioning Peer. While anyone can produce events to be journaled, or consume events from a Journal, the concept of a Provisioning Peer allows you to pre-define and centrally-manage producers and consumers in order to support filters, maintain cursors, and additional information about the peer. Additionally, when a Provisioning Peer produces an event, the peerId should be provided in order to avoid event loopback situations, where a consumer could consume the very event it produced.
